AUSTRALIA

Adelaide Brighton (ABC AT) - Co. talks remain ongoing regarding potential merger with Barro Group’s JV Independent Cement and Lime. (Newswires)

Cromwell Property (CMW AT) - Co. FY net AUD 159.9mln vs. Prev. AUD 204.1mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Crown Resorts (CWN AT) - Melco has reportedly put plans to buy James Packer’s shares on hold, while other reports noted Melco agreed to amend share sale pact and is waiting on result of the NSW Liquor and Gaming Authority inquiry. (Newswires)

Decmil Group (DCG AT) - Co. FY19 net AUD 14.0mln vs. Prev. loss AUD 6.1mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Independence Group (IGO AT) - Co. final FY19 net AUD 76.1mln vs. Prev. AUD 52.7mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Link Administration Holdings (LNK AT) - Co. FY19 net AUD 319.0mln vs. Prev. AUD 142.0mln Y/Y, to repurchase as much as 10% of outstanding shares. (Newswires)

Lynas (LYC AT) - Co. FY19 net AUD 80.0mln vs. Prev. AUD 53.1mln Y/Y, rev. AUD 363.5mln vs. Prev. AUD 374.1mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Perenti Global (formerly Ausdrill) (ASL AT) - Co. FY19 net AUD 181.3mln vs. Prev. AUD 61.1mln Y/Y, rev. AUD 1.64bln vs. Prev. AUD 887.3mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Ramsay Health Care (RHC AT) - Co. FY19 net AUD 590.9mln vs. Exp. AUD 583.0mln, rev. AUD 11.55bln vs. Exp. AUD 11.40bln. (Newswires) 

Woolworths (WOW AT) - Woolworths (WOW AT) FY19 net AUD 2.7bln vs. Prev. AUD 1.7bln Y/Y, after-tax profit cont. ops. AUD fell 7% to AUD 1.49bln, rev. AUD 59.98bln vs. Prev. AUD 57.2bln Y/Y, Co. declares dividend of AUD 0.57/Shr and is thought to be mulling exiting Big W business. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Japan Post Insurance (7181 JT) - Co. is to extend halt of insurance policies for now. (Newswires)

Recruit Holdings (6098 JT) - Co. will sell shares in Japan and abroad for shareholders in which 116.7mln shares will be offered, while the Co. will repurchase as much as 1.8% of shares for JPY 80bln. (Newswires)

TEPCO (9501 JT) - Co. reaches agreement with Chubu Electric Power (9502 JT), Hitachi (6501 JT) and Toshiba (6502 JT) to look to create a framework for safe and efficient construction, operation, maintenance and decommissioning of nuclear power plants. (Newswires)

Toyota (7203 JT) - Co. is to offer private label financing services for Mazda Motor (7261 JT), while Toyota is also said to be in the final stages of an equity tie-up with Suzuki (7269 JT). (Newswires)

Other News - South Korea is to file a WTO complaint against Japan after the latter recently formally imposed additional trade restrictions. (Nikkei)

Geopolitics

North Korea Parliament is conducting a rare 2nd meeting for the year today, with media speculating it is to rubber stamp a decision from leadership regarding ongoing issues with missile tests or about talks with South Korea and/or US President Trump. (Yonhap)

South Korea government is analysing seawater after reports that a North Korean uranium factory may have leaked waste into the West Sea. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said he could do a quick deal with China and be a hero in a phone in to the Farm Progress Show, while he also stated that China was supposed to buy corn but did not do it. (Newswires)

US VP Pence's Chief of Staff Short commented that we cannot say when a China deal will happen but added there have been calls between the sides and that he is optimistic about a deal. (Fox News)

US Navy warship conducted a "Freedom of Navigation" operation in the South China sea today, according to a US military spokesperson. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson announced to end the current parliamentary session from the second sitting week in September and reconvene Parliament on October 14th with the Queen’s speech, while he denied that he is attempting to sideline parliament on the Brexit and said lawmakers will have ample time to debate Brexit both before and after the crucial October 17th-18th EU Council summit. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson's Brexit advisor Frost reportedly told EU officials today that government wanted a deal and downplayed the prorogation move, while Frost reiterated current backstop was not acceptable for the UK and it was separately reported that UK and EU agree to intensify discussions from next week. (FT/Guardian/Twitter)

UK Downing Street source stated that if MPs pass a no confidence vote next week, then we'll stay in No.10 and won't recommend any alternative government, while the source added we'll dissolve Parliament and have an election between 1st-5th November which means no time for legislation. Furthermore, a source commented lawyers are absolutely confident that the courts cannot interfere with the Queen’s speech process and that process of proroguing parliament is ancient so there no scope for legislation to stop it, according to ITV's Peston. (Twitter)

House Speaker Bercow said the move represents a constitutional outrage and that however it is dressed up, it is blindingly obvious that the purpose of prorogation now would be to stop Parliament debating Brexit and performing its duty, according to BBC’s Kuenssberg. (Twitter)

UK Tory Lawmaker Grieve said UK Parliament could move quickly on no confidence against PM Johnson which is now more likely, while FT's Payne also tweeted that the most likely impact of the 5-week prorogation is to bring forward a vote of no confidence against UK PM Johnson to next week although anti no-deal MPs all-but admitted yesterday they don’t have the numbers for it to pass. (Twitter)

UK opposition leader Corbyn said opposition MPs will continue efforts to pass a law to prevent a no-deal and will also keep the option open for a vote of no confidence, while Corbyn was also said to have written to the Queen to express concerns over the proroguing of parliament and requested a meeting. (Twitter/ITV/Guardian)

Labour MP Ian Murray said a cross-party group of more than 70 MPs will now consider seeking an interim interdict in a Court of Session to block prorogation with the hearing to be scheduled for 6th September, while there were comments from an anti no-deal lawmaker that MPs are confident they still have legislative time and procedural ability to block PM Johnson's prorogation plan. (Newswires/Sky/Twitter)

EU Brexit Coordinator Verhofstadt was negative on today's Brexit events in which he stated 'taking back control' has never looked so sinister and that he is in solidarity with lawmakers fighting for their voices to be heard, while he added that suppressing debate on profound choices is unlikely to help deliver a stable future EU/UK relationship. There were also comments from an EU source that there is a strong sense that no-deal has just become even more of a likely possibility than it was before. (Newswires/Sun)

Irish Foreign Minister Coveney reiterated that the Withdrawal Agreement cannot be renegotiated, while he added that it cannot be done in 6-10 weeks and that backstop alternatives must do the same job as the backstop. (Newswires)

Italy's Di Maio said that after meeting President Mattarella, he was told there was a political accord with PD that Conte should be PM, while he added that their programme remains the same as always and the League asked him to be PM in a new government but he is interested in the country not his personal ambition. (Newswires) 

 

FX

 

SNB's Maechler said uncertainty level is quite high and greater than at the first Brexit vote as well as 2016 US election, while Swiss inflation pressures remain very weak and that expansionary monetary policy remains needed. Furthermore, Maechler commented that the attractiveness of the Swiss Franc has enormously increased although a negative rate helps reduce the Franc's attractiveness and that the SNB stills have plenty of room for FX intervention. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks -10.027M vs. Exp. -2.112M (Prev. -2.7M). (Newswires) 

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif tweeted that he had constructive talks with Japanese PM Abe on "reducing tensions in the Persian Gulf and preserving benefits of JCPOA for the Iranian people". In related news, there were reports the US Treasury targets procurement networks supporting Iran's missile proliferation programs with sanctions and that one network used Hong Kong-based front company to evade US and international sanctions, while two Iranian government-linked networks engaged in covert procurement activity benefiting Iranian military organisations. (Newswires)

 

US

US President Trump reiterated criticisms of the Fed in which he suggested the Fed has no clue and cannot “mentally” keep up with the competition, while he also noted that leaders of other countries at the G-7 in France were giddy about how low their interest costs have gone with Germany actually “getting paid” to borrow money. (Twitter)

Fed's Barkin (non-voter) said he is not yet persuaded on the weak inflation part of the case for a rate cut but is watching risks to growth closely and is holding his decision on rate policy until he gets to the September meeting. (Newswires) 

 

MARKET RECAP

Markets gave somewhat mixed signals on Wednesday with equities, bonds, DX and energy firmer on the day, with the ever focused on 2s10s inversion reaching 0.6bps before halving into the close. Equities caught a bid going into the US session, albeit the SPX failed to breach Tuesday's high of 2898, with the tech sector restraining indices as Autodesk (ADSK) weighed on cloud providers (MSFT, ADBE, CRM, ORCL) after pessimistic guidance. There was a spell of textbook risk-on around the US equity open as Treasuries, XAU, and JPY saw some selling pressure whilst equities had their time to shine. However, a dismal earnings report and guidance from Autodesk (ADSK) saw the stock plummet, and provided pressure on other cloud players (MSFT, ADBE, ORCL, CRM). Strong crude oil prices boosted the energy sector in general. Coty (COTY) outperformed after its optimistic guidance. Brown Forman (BF.B) hit on lower Jack Daniels demand. Tiffany (TIF) suffered from pessimistic earnings and guidance. Phillip Morris (PM) was higher following its strong sell-off on Tuesday on the announcement of the Altria (MO) merger talks. S&P 500 +0.7% at 2888, NASDAQ-100 0.3% at 7588, Dow Jones 1% at 26036.

The TPLEX again moved higher on Wednesday despite firmer equity indices, catching steam on the back of a strong 5-year Note auction; some desks were also attributing the growing risk of a no-deal Brexit as a tailwind. Yields continued to exacerbate their inversion with the 2s10s testing just shy of -0.6bps; on the outlook Nordea noted that inversions deepen for two to three months usually – once initially inverted - based on the past five inversions. The 5-year Note auction saw a chunky 1bps stop through the screens with the B/C ratio at 2.48x (avg. 2.36x); both indirects and dealers took above their six-auction averages, leaving less for dealers in what was evidently a strong auction. At settlement the curve was actually steeper, expect in the belly- to long-end, with Treasury yields lower between 1.5bps to 2.5bps. US T-note futures (U9) settled 7 ticks higher at 131.11+.

content:

US MARKET WRAP 28th August 2019: No Deal more likely as UK Parliament heads for prorogation

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities higher, Treasuries higher, Dollar higher, Crude higher

* REAR VIEW: UK Parliament heads for prorogation, solid 5-year auction, larger API & DOE draws, 5SM&PD reach an agreement

* COMING UP: Data: Australian Capital Expenditure, French GDP (Final), German CPI (Prelim) & Unemployment Rate, EZ Sentiment, US GDP (2nd Estimate), Core PCE Prices & Initial Jobless Claims. Events: Banxico Minutes, Speakers: Fed’s Daly, Supply from Italy & US. Earnings: Dollar General, Dollar Tree & Pernod Ricard

 

* MARKET WRAP: Markets gave somewhat mixed signals on Wednesday with equities, bonds, DX and energy firmer on the day, with the ever focused on 2s10s inversion reaching 0.6bps before halving into the close. Equities caught a bid going into the US session, albeit the SPX failed to breach Tuesday's high of 2898, with the tech sector restraining indices as Autodesk (ADSK) weighed on cloud providers (MSFT, ADBE, CRM, ORCL) after pessimistic guidance. There was a spell of textbook risk-on around the US equity open as Treasuries, XAU, and JPY saw some selling pressure whilst equities had their time to shine. However, a strong US 5-year Note auction brought bidders to the TPLEX and fed through to appetite for bullion whilst bringing equities off their highs. Crude prices held their API induced gains as the EIA affirmed a 10mln barrel draw in US crude stocks, although came off highs into settlement. Elsewhere, US participants seemingly shrugged off concerns of the increasingly likely No Deal Brexit, an often-cited Fed concern, which did see GBP weaker after her majesty approved PM Johnson's request to suspend parliament to avoid MP efforts to block a no-deal. BTP's moved higher through the European session on positive hopes for the Italian government, hopes which were later vindicated as the 5SM and PD came to a political accord for a Conte-lead, new government.

* BREXIT: The Queen has accepted a request by the government to prorogue Parliament (no earlier than 9th September, and no later than 12th September, and running through 14th October), a move that limits options for pro-European lawmakers that want to pass legislation to extend Article 50 and delay a no deal Brexit. Reports suggest that there would be a small window next week and the week after for MPs to attempt to pass some legislation, although the consensus view is that may not be enough time. Given the argument that the EU has been on the sidelines, awaiting moves by pro-European MPs to take action to stop Brexit, before making any commitment to re-open the Withdrawal Agreement, today's moves will put pressure on the bloc to compromise on the Irish backstop (a notion already dismissed by the Irish finance minister today). It also increases the probability of an accidental no deal Brexit, and earlier General Elections. Some journalists suggested that the likely impact of the five-week prorogation will be to bring forward votes of no confidence in PM Johnson's government next week, although some anti-Brexit MPs have reportedly admitted they lack numbers. From a legal perspective, watchers also noted that the legal options to prevent prorogation are also limited. Click here for further analysis.

* US/CHINA: US President Trump reiterated his well-known stance, that the US was doing well on China. However, White House Security Advisor Bolton, a China Hawk, stated that the US and China have significant differences over trade, and he reiterated that China was stealing US’ intellectual property for decades. The Chief of Staff to VP Pence was more sanguine and said there have been calls between US and China, and that he himself was optimistic, but it was unclear when a deal will happen. Meanwhile, following last week’s request from US President Trump for US companies to pull out of China, Nikkei reported Alphabet (GOOGL) is to move its Pixel smartphone production from China to Vietnam. Elsewhere, WSJ reported that US Officials are looking to block an undersea cable backed by Google, Facebook (FB) and a Chinese partner on the back national security concerns; which could reportedly rewrite the rules of internet connectivity between the two nations. In a procedural move, the US Federal Register confirmed President Trump’s latest moves to to raise tariffs on USD 300bln of Chinese goods to 15% from 10% beginning on Sept 1st, while there were separate reports that China will take in the 2nd batch of tariff exemption applications on September 2nd.

* IRAN: The US Treasury has sanctioned two networks it says have helped Iran’s nuclear programme in its latest efforts to place “maximum pressure” on Tehran, and just days after the positive comments made at the G7 by both US President Trump and French President Macron. One of the networks allegedly uses a Hong Kong-based front company in order to evade US and international sanctions, potentially giving a “shoe-in” for US intervention in Hong Kong.

* TURKEY/RUSSIA: Russian and Turkey are reportedly discussing the deliveries of Russian made SU-35 and SU-57 aircraft to Turkey and are also pondering collaborating on creating a new fighter jet. This will likely not go down well for Turkey in Washington, where tensions are already fragile over Turkey’s decision to purchase the Russian S-400 missile defence system, a red-line for the US who has since banned Turkey from the F-35 fighter jet programme. 

* ITALY: The 5SM and PD came to a political accord to form a government with Conte as PM, who is reportedly going to be sworn in tomorrow morning at 0930 BST by President Mattarella. However, earlier reports did suggest 5SM leader Di Maio's personal ambitions are blocking a final agreement. BTPs have strengthened this week, implying a belief that a 5SM/PD coalition would keep Italy's public deficit beneath the 3%/GDP EU target in 2020. The deal will likely lend further strength to Italian bonds, analysts said, with the 10-year yield on Wednesday seeing fresh record lows under 1%; but higher relative Italian yields, and the prospect of ECB easing in September are also likely to provide tailwinds for Italian debt, some strategists reasoned. Indeed, the ECB's upcoming meeting may perhaps be one of the reasons why the Bund/BTP spread has not been able to exert its influence on the EUR in this summer's Italian crisis.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLED 7 TICKS HIGHER AT 131.11+: The TPLEX again moved higher on Wednesday despite firmer equity indices, catching steam on the back of a strong 5-year Note auction; some desks were also attributing the growing risk of a no-deal Brexit as a tailwind. Yields continued to exacerbate their inversion with the 2s10s testing just shy of -0.6bps; on the outlook Nordea noted that inversions deepen for two to three months usually – once initially inverted - based on the past five inversions. The 5-year Note auction saw a chunky 1bps stop through the screens with the B/C ratio at 2.48x (avg. 2.36x); both indirects and dealers took above their six-auction averages, leaving less for dealers in what was evidently a strong auction. At settlement the curve was actually steeper, expect in the belly- to long-end, with Treasury yields lower between 1.5bps to 2.5bps.

* THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The Treasury will this week sell a new 2-year note (Tue, USD 40bln), new 5-year note (Wed, USD 41bln) and new 7-year note (Thu, USD 32bln). Analysts at UBS say this week will bring USD 85bln of cash (excluding SOMA holdings) but including around USD 76bln of redemption, as well as around USD 8.5bln of coupons.

* 7- YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: SocGen's strategists say the 7-year sector trades cheap in asset swap versus older 7s, but trades fair on the curve against 5s and 10s. Last month's auction was weak, tailing and seeing the softest cover since February 2016. SocGen says the sale will likely need concession this month, since the current when-issued trades below all stop out rates since 2016, and as such, the bank says it is negative on the auction.

* WTI (V9) SETTLES USD 0.85 HIGHER AT USD 55.78/BBL; BRENT (X9) SETTLES USD 0.90 HIGHER AT USD 59.93/BBL: A bullish API inventory report (which was later vindicated by the official EIA release) and firmer risk appetite saw crude benchmarks both push over one buck higher on Wednesday, before paring back into settlement. EIA reported US crude stocks drawing a hefty 10mln bbls (exp. -2.5mln), albeit slightly smaller than the API reported 11.1mln draw; the products surprised to bullish side with both gasoline (exp. -0.4mln) and distillates (exp. +0.9mln) drawing 2.1mln bbls, whilst Cushing stocks drew 2mln bbls. A 0.2mln BPD rise in crude exports, coupled by a 1.3mln BPD fall in imports saw net imports fall to 2.9mln BPD, where a new record production of 12.5mln BPD likely reduced refiners’ need for imported crude; refinery utilisation fell by 0.7% (exp. -0.3%). Elsewhere, Morgan Stanley is the latest forecaster to lowers its oil demand growth estimates: 2019 to 800k BPD (Prev. 1.0mln BPD), 2020 to 1.0mln BPD (Prev. 1.4mln BPD), and now sees Brent prices fluctuating around USD 60/bbl (Prev. USD 65/bbl).

S&P 500 0.7% at 2888, NASDAQ-100 0.3% at 7588, Dow Jones 1% at 26036, S&P 500 SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary  1.1%, Consumer Staples  0.9%, Energy  1.4%, Financials  0.9%, Health Care  0.7%, Industrials  1.1%, Information Technology  0.1%, Materials  0.9%, Telecommunication Services  0.5%, Utilities  -0.3%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: A dismal earnings report and guidance from Autodesk (ADSK) saw the stock plummet, and provided pressure on other cloud players (MSFT, ADBE, ORCL, CRM). Strong crude oil prices boosted the energy sector in general. Coty (COTY) outperformed after its optimistic guidance. Brown Forman (BF.B) hit on lower Jack Daniels demand. Tiffany (TIF) suffered from pessimistic earnings and guidance. Phillip Morris (PM) was higher following its strong sell-off on Tuesday on the announcement of the Altria (MO) merger talks.

* FX WRAP:

GBP unlike Tuesday, was the underperforming currency on Wednesday as the Queen approved the request to prorogue parliament from no sooner than September 9th and no later than September 12th, until October 14th; limiting time for the Anti-No Deal team to put together a legislative way to prevent a no deal. GBPUSD initially breached 1.22 to the downside however the moves were pared back above the key level and the cross remained above it throughout the rest of the session.

EUR was lower against the dollar after SocGen touted towards ECB releasing an open-ended QE programme at the September meeting (EUR 40bln per month). The cross also had chunky option expiries, 1.8bln worth, at the 1.11 strike; however, the cross traded beneath this level heading into the NY cut. The single currency shrugged off weak import/export prices from Germany, however GfK Consumer Sentiment did surprise slightly to the upside. EURUSD was relatively rangebound today, however it has declined for three consecutive sessions and threats heading towards the 2019 low of 1.1027.

ANTIPODES: Roles continue to reverse down under where the Antipodean Dollars are both weaker vs their US counterpart, but the Kiwi has replaced the Aussie as whipping boy down under, as NZDUSD slips further towards 0.6325 vs AUDUSD holding within a 0.6762-35 range and AUDNZD firmly above 1.0600 between 1.0605-50.

Havens: USDJPY traded relatively rangebound throughout the early morning session, however as risk appetitive improved once the US session took course, the pair caught wind and drifted through the 106 handle in later trade and found resistance at Tuesday’s high and 10dma of 106.15/16. XAU trended higher prior to the US open but sold off once the US session was underway and remained lower heading into APAC trade. The precious metal did see some volatility heading into settlement as the Aug19 futures expired. CHF relatively flat on the day and seemingly unphased by Maechler’s comments of scope for more FX intervention.

SNB: SNB’s Maechler said Swiss inflation pressures remain very weak, and expansionary monetary policy remains needed. On the Franc, Maechler said its attractiveness had enormously increased, where a negative rate is helping to reduce that; adding that there is still plenty of room for FX intervention. Maechler noted that the current uncertainty level is quite high, referencing it as higher than it was at the first Brexit vote and 2016 US election.

EM: BRL unwound gains from the central bank intervention the prior day from further dovish BCB commentary, MXN was lower after Banxico released its QIR where it cut its 2019 and 2020 growth forecasts, as well as its year end 2019 inflation forecast;  maintaining its year end 2020 forecast. The ARS was also lower despite central bank intervention which, according to traders, once again breached the IMF’s daily guidance as it sold a further USD 367mln of reserves across 7 separate interventions.  TRY outperformed with the aid of improved Turkish consumer morale whereas RUB failed to shrug off sanctions and the loss of local tax payment demand.

content:
* THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The Treasury will this week sell a new 2-year note (Tue, USD 40bln), new 5-year note (Wed, USD 41bln) and new 7-year note (Thu, USD 32bln). Analysts at UBS say this week will bring USD 85bln of cash (excluding SOMA holdings) but including around USD 76bln of redemption, as well as around USD 8.5bln of coupons.

* 5-YEAR PREVIEW: The 5-year sector lacks clear set-up from a relative value perspective, SocGen says, with the bank noting that the current 5-year note is trading fair in asset swap versus older 5s, though trades rich on the curve against 2s and 10s. The previous 5s auction was poor, seeing the lowest cover since December 2018. SocGen's analysts also note that dealer holdings in the 3-6 year are high, meaning that the participation of foreign and investment funds will be key. "For the auction to go well, it will likely need a concession as the current when-issued yield for the sector is trading well below all auction stops since October 2016." The bank says it is negative on Wednesday's auction, saying that it may see an unscheduled reopening of an old 7-year note (the 1.875% august 2024 note) if the high yield is in the range of 1.875% to 1.999%.* THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The Treasury will this week sell a new 2-year note (Tue, USD 40bln), new 5-year note (Wed, USD 41bln) and new 7-year note (Thu, USD 32bln). subject: Daily FX Wrap: tide turns across the Channel and Tasman Sea
content:
GBP/NZD/SEK/NOK

Well off worst levels, but the Pound remains at the bottom of the G10 table after confirmation via the Privy Council Office that the Queen has approved the request to prorogue parliament from no sooner than September 9 and no later than the 12th until October 14. This effectively limits the time available for the anti-no deal Brexit brigade to enact legislation ahead of the October 31 deadline given that MPs are only due to return from Summer recess on September 3. Hence, if PM Johnson fails to present compatible alternatives to the Irish backstop and the EU remains adamant that the WA that includes the current border arrangement is written in stone, the odds of Britain leaving without an accord appear to have shortened again. Cable is clinging to 1.2200 and Eur/Gbp holding midway between 0.9024-0.9124, but the cross is still prone to RHS demand for month end. Meanwhile, roles continue to reverse down under where the Antipodean Dollars are both weaker vs their US counterpart, but the Kiwi has replaced the Aussie as whipping boy down under, as Nzd/Usd slips further towards 0.6325 vs Aud/Usd holding within a 0.6762-35 range and Aud/Nzd firmly above 1.0600 between 1.0605-45. Similarly, the Scandi Crowns continue to dovetail, and after a run of upbeat Swedish data underpinned the Sek through swings in broad risk sentiment a firmer recovery in oil is now helping the Nok to contain losses vs the Eur around 10.0230 compared to 10.7800 for its Krona rival. 

EUR/JPY/CAD

All softer against the Greenback, as the DXY edges up to a marginal new session high (98.227) and the Euro loses a bit more ground amidst another dovish ECB call (open-ended asset purchases touted by a French bank). Moreover, any pull exerted by a decent option expiry interest at 1.1100 (1.8 bn) disappeared when that rolled off, and the Yen also slipped towards 106.00 again when 1.1 bn expired unscathed between 105.75-80. However, the aforementioned crude revival did help the Loonie recover from circa 1.3315 to 1.3280 at one stage, with EIA inventories also revealing a much bigger draw than expected in line with API stocks on Tuesday.

EM

Some regional currencies recouped losses vs the Usd, while the Try actually outperformed with the aid of improved Turkish consumer morale, but the Brl was hampered by more dovish BCB commentary and the Ars markedly underperformed even though the Central Bank intervened 3 times compared to the usual twice a day ops. Similarly, the Rub could not shrug off sanctions and the loss of local tax payment demand.

subject: ANALYSIS: Potential Parliament prorogation ahead
content:
Snapshot

  • PM Johnson is to attempt to prorogue parliament from September 9th for around 5 weeks to return on October 14th for the Queens speech and then subsequent debates and votes on the speech. In terms of context, this leaves a short window of opportunity from Parliaments return on September 3rd to pass legislation to prevent a no-deal Brexit.

Details

  • UK politics has erupted today ahead of the official return of parliament on September 3rd next week. UK PM Johnson has confirmed that parliament will be suspended from around September 9th, and October’s party conference recess to be extended by one week until October 14th for the Queen’s speech.
  • In terms of timings, the prorogation will indicatively take place from September 9th (though some reports do indicate September 11th instead), for around 5 weeks with Parliament to return on October 14th for the Queen’s speech. While some have noted that such a move by the UK Government is unacceptable etc., indications are that it is perfectly legal for this to occur and that there is no scope for legislation to stop the routine process around the Queen’s speech. Regarding the length of the break, while it is somewhat longer than typical as the prior Queen’s speech was two years ago the extended length maybe a justifiable reflection of that.
  • Upon Parliaments return on October 14th, this time will be taken up by debated on the Queen’s speech and then subsequent votes on it leaving very little time to prevent a no-deal; particularly as the European Council conference is on the 17-18th October, which is the effective date for a deal to be agreed upon before the October 31st extension end.
  • As such, the two weeks between September 3rd and 9th/11th are the most likely opportunity for any legislation to stop a no-deal, which has scope as Opposition Leaders have agreed to table a law with the intent of stopping a no-deal alongside over 200 MPs yesterday signing a declaration to continue to run parliament elsewhere in the event it is suspended. On the possibility of a no-confidence vote, this is possible however recently opposition politicians have stated that they do not have the support required for such a vote and that it is their last resort.

Dates:

  • September 3rd: Parliament Returns
  • September 5th: Potential date for a General Election to be called
  • September 9th -11th: Parliament Suspended
  • September 19th: BoE Rate Decision
  • September 22nd- 25th: Labour Party Conference
  • September 28th – October 2nd: Tory Party Conference
  • October 14th: Queen’s Speech
  • October 17th: Potential General Election date (if called on September 5th)
  • October 17th- 18th: European Council Meeting (Informal deadline for a Brexit deal to be agreed)
  • October 21st – 22nd: Votes on the Queen’s Speech
  • October 31st: Scheduled Brexit date
  • November 7th: BoE Rate Decision and QIR

Ability to Block No-Deal

  • Parliaments prorogation makes the possibility of no-deal being blocked via legislation or a no-confidence vote significantly less likely. The likelihood of this is further reduced if other possible measures the government could used to fill the available time are taken into account, such as holding the budget in October after the Queen’s speech. Hence, the risk of a no-deal is more prominent, illustrated by Sterling’s slip today.
  • In terms of the legislative route, ING notes this encompasses the passing of legislation to force the PM to ask for another Article 50 extension. A process which would heavily rely on House Speaker Bercow, due to his role in Parliamentary scheduling. Bercow’s support to this route is like given his comments today in response to the suspension of parliament that ‘this move represents a constitutional outrage, blindingly obvious that the prorogation is to stop Parliament debating Brexit and performing their duty’.
  • Regarding a no-confidence vote, this is possible but the Opposition have made it clear that their preferred method is the legislative route. Recent narrative on a no-confidence vote from opposition MP’s indicates that they do not believe they have the required amount of support in the House to win a no-confidence vote.

GBP

  • ING see further pressure on Sterling in the weeks ahead as the risk of a no-deal Brexit has risen, and will likely increase further as the window of opportunity prior to parliaments suspension on around September 9th closes. Specifically, ING call for EUR/GBP to retest its multi-year high at 0.9325 towards the middle of October as the European Commission summit approaches.

Scenario Analysis via ING

DOW

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc Class A (GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) is looking to move production of its Pixel smartphone out of China and into Vietnam in efforts to build a low-cost supply chain, where it is looking to avoid higher Chinese labour costs and tariffs, Nikkei reported.
  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is reaching out to content providers (movies and TV) to obtain more exclusive licenses for its ad-supported IMDb TV streaming service, WSJ reports. The newspaper also said that Amazon is in preliminary talks for a collaboration with Gojek, an Indonesian ride-hailing firm, in which it might choose to make a substantial investment. Washington Post reported that Amazon’s video doorbell, Ring, has quietly been partnering with police forces in the US to grant them access to footage.
  • Autodesk Inc. (ADSK) (Information Technology/Application Software) Q2 20 (USD): adj. EPS 0.65 (exp. 0.62), Revenue 0.78bln (exp. 0.79bln); Cloud ARR increased 175% to USD 207mln. Co cut FY revenue guidance to 3.24bln-3.27bln (exp. 3.29bln); also cut FY adj. EPS view 2.69-2.81 (exp. 2.82); “takes into consideration the current economic environment and foreign exchange currency rate environment.”
  • Costco Wholesale Corp. (COST) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) has had to put people limits on its new - and first - Chinese store in a Shanghai suburb, where overcrowding forced it too shut early on its opening day.
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) has been failing to provide adequate data to independent researchers which FB promised to assist in their assessment of how the social media platform impacts elections, FT reports. Elsewhere, FB is tightening its political advertisement rules by introducing new disclosure requirements and a “confirmed organisation” label.

S&P 500

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 28th August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are softer with the exception of the FTSE 100 on Sterling weakness as prorogation becomes possible
  • PM Johnson is attempting to prorogue parliament from September 9th until October 14th , leaving around a two week period to prevent a no-deal Brexit
  • Italy’s PD party have backed Leader Zingaretti’s request for a mandate to form a coalition, Italian 10yr yield at record lows
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, DoEs, Fed Beige Book, Fed’s Barkin & US USD 41bln 5yr auction

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets struggled for direction after the subdued performance on Wall St, where the major indices failed to sustain initial gains amid the recent mixed signals on US-China trade and as the US yield curve inversion deepened. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was led higher by strength in tech and miners although gains were capped by weakness amid telecoms as and with earnings in focus, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) also lacked firm direction amid an uneventful currency. Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) traded tentatively and failed to benefit from the government’s recent announced measures to boost consumption with markets wary after the recent flip-flopping in the US-China trade saga, while a neutral PBoC liquidity operation and deluge of earnings ahead of the Big 4 bank results added to the cautious tone. Finally, 10yr JGBs were slightly higher as super-long yields declined to multi-year lows with both 30yr and 40yr JGB yields at the lowest since July 2016, while the moves also followed the bull flattening seen in their US counterparts where the 2s/10s inversion briefly widened past -5bps.

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 28-day reverse repo for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0835 vs. Exp. 7.1027 (Prev. 7.0810)

China issued 20 directives to boost domestic consumption which reportedly will make it increasingly difficult for the US to press China to make concessions including gradually relaxing and removing restrictions on auto purchases, as well as building more shopping malls and rolling out state-of-the-art methods for consumers to spend money. (Global Times)

US Federal Register confirmed the US is to raise tariffs on USD 300bln of Chinese goods to 15% from 10% beginning on Friday, while there were separate reports that China will to take in the 2nd batch of tariff exemption applications on September 2nd. (Newswires)

US President Trump’s credibility has become a key obstacle for China with respect to them reaching a deal with the US., according to Chinese officials. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Photos reportedly suggested North Korea could be building a submarine capable of launching nuclear missiles. (NBC)

US House of Foreign Affairs Committee tweeted that US President Trump must sanction Turkey over its purchase of the S-400 air defense system as required by US law. (Newswires)

Russian and Turkey are reportedly discussing the deliveries of russian made SU-35 and SU-57 aircraft to Turkey., according to RIA citing a Russian Official. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Surmising UK Parliament updates: PM Johnson is to attempt to prorogue parliament from September 9th for around 5 weeks to return on October 14th for the Queens speech and then subsequent debates and votes on the speech. In terms of the context, this essentially leaves the two weeks from Parliaments return on September 3rd to pass legislation to prevent a no-deal Brexit. Full analysis available here

UK opposition Labour Party leader Corbyn urged Tory MPs to help block no-deal Brexit, while it was separately reported that former chancellor Hammond plans to spearhead efforts to block a no-deal and intends to advocate a cross-party plan to force a Brexit delay by several months. (Newswires/Telegraph)

UK government is reportedly planning to declare an intention to raise public spending beginning September 4th. However, there were separate reports that UK Chancellor Javid will warn today that the government will not break fiscal rules heading into the Brexit and will not issue blank cheques to Whitehall departments. (FT/Telegraph)

Italy’s PD party have back Leader Zingaretti’s request for a mandate to form a coalition (Newswires)

Prior to this, Italy Deputy PM Di Maio said the 5-Star leadership will support a new government only if party members approve it through an online vote planned by next week. PD are willing to accept Conte as PM of a new government, although they wish to limit the role of current Deputy PM Di Maio (5SM), according to a PD Official. Italy's PD Deputy Leader Orlando says that the nation's next deputy PM should come from their party and not the 5SM, according to a Tweet (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are lower across the board [Eurostoxx 50 -0.6%] with the exception of the FTSE 100 (+0.3%) as exporters benefit from a weaker Sterling amid reports that UK PM Johnson is said to be moving to block attempts by pro-EU MPs from making a no-deal Brexit impossible. Sectors are mostly in the red with underperformance seen in the IT sectors, potentially amid reports that Permira is planning a Frankfurt listing for software company TeamViewer GmbH this year which could be the Germany’s largest IPO in almost 20 years. Meanwhile, the energy sector is the marked outperformer as oil prices are underpinned by a larger-than-forecast draw in API crude inventories. In terms of individual movers, H&M (+4.4%) shares are at the top of the Stoxx 600 amid an upgrade at RBC. Meanwhile, losses in UK homebuilders exacerbated amid the aforementioned move by UK PM Johnson. Elsewhere, AstraZeneca (+1.2%) trades higher after an FDA granted an orphan drug designation and after its Breztro Aerosphere Phase III trial met its primary endpoint.

Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) to shift Pixel smartphone production from China to Vietnam, according to Nikkei. (Nikkei)

 

Toyota (7203 JT) & Suzuki (7269 JT) are to reportedly enter a capital alliance, via NHK, Toyota to invest around JPY 96bln in Suzuki for a stake of around 5%. (Newswires)

FX

GBP - A week may be a long time in politics, but for Sterling 24 hours is all it has taken to turn from major outperformer to laggard as Brexit positivity evaporates and the prospect of a no confidence vote in the UK Government rises on the back of PM Johnson’s request to the Queen to suspend Parliament. In short, the move is being framed as a tactical decision to head off legislative attempts to stop a no deal Brexit by curtailing the amount of time between the now delayed Queen’s speech (October 14 from 7 originally) and October 31 Article 50 extension date. In response, Cable tumbled from just under 1.2300 to circa 1.2156 and not far from technical support around 1.2150 in the form of the 21 DMA at 1.2149, while Eur/Gbp rebounded almost a full point towards 0.9125 before the Pound pared some lost ground.

USD - The Dollar is obviously deriving indirect impetus from Sterling’s demise, but also firmer against all G10 counterparts bar the Euro that is holding close to 1.1100 on more progress towards a new Italian political partnership between the PD and 5-Star Movement. Hence, the DXY is consolidating above the 98.000 level, albeit within a confined 98.173-003 range ahead of a couple of Fed speakers and the latest Beige Book.

NZD/CAD/AUD/JPY/CHF - As noted above, all weaker vs the Greenback, albeit to varying degrees as the Kiwi slips back below 0.6350 and towards 1.0650 against the Aussie that is pivoting 0.6750 and only partially impeded by overnight data showing considerably weaker than forecast Q2 construction work. Meanwhile, the Loonie is still straddling 1.3300 as fragile/weak risk sentiment offsets firm crude prices, with the Yen and Franc regaining some safe-haven allure, but remaining off recent peaks, as Usd/Jpy hovers near 105.75 and Usd/Chf meanders between 0.9810-30. Note, several hefty option expiries could have a bearing on direction into Wednesday’s NY cut including 1.8 bn in Eur/Usd at the 1.1100 strike, 1 bn in Aud/Usd from 0.6700-10 and 1.1 bn in Usd/Jpy between 105.75-80.

EM - Broad weakness vs the Buck, but the Lira deriving comfort from another significant improvement in Turkish sentiment and this time on the consumer front. Indeed, Usd/Try is probing 5.8000 support even though Turkey and Russia are pressing ahead with more arms deal plans and the US House of Foreign Affairs Committee is urging President Trump to sanction Turkey. Conversely, the Rouble and Rand are not benefiting from the rebound in Brent and latest SA economic package respectively.

Australian Construction Work Done Q2 -3.8% vs. Exp. -1.0% (Prev. -1.9%, Rev. -2.2%). (Newswires)

FIXED

Gilts and BTPs are extending earlier gains, and perversely or ironically, as the UK Government is on the brink of shutdown in contrast to a new coalition getting closer to fruition in Italy. The former hit 134.65 and latter 145.79 with corresponding 10 year yields plumbing lows of around 0.45% and 1.025% respectively. Meanwhile, Bunds have now surpassed Monday’s Eurex high, at 179.24 vs 179.21, while the US Treasury curve has flattened/inverted further with the 2-10 spread at -6 bp earlier and long bond down to 1.91%.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are higher as prices are underpinned by last night’s API crude inventory data which printed a significantly larger-than-forecast draw in API crude stocks (-11.1mln vs. Exp. -2.1mln). WTI futures reside north of 55.50/bbl ahead of its 200 and 50 DMAs at 560.7/bbl and 56.53/bbl respectively, whist its Brent counterpart remains just above 60/bbl. ING point out that the WTI/Brent Arb has narrowed further after initially feeling pressure from China’s 5% tariff on US oil. Elsewhere, gold prices remain flat just under the 1550/oz mark whilst copper are modestly firmer with the red metal back above the 2.55/lb mark. Finally, Dalian iron ore prices fell to the lowest in 2 ½ months as falling steel prices continue to raise concerns regarding iron ore demand.

Morgan Stanley lowers oil demand growth forecasts: 2019 to 800k BPD (Prev. 1.0mln BPD), 2020 to 1.0mln BPD (Prev. 1.4mln BPD), Brent prices are now expected to fluctuate around USD 60/bbl (Prev. USD 65/bbl)

- Lowers WTI Q3 and Q4 forecasts to USD 55.0/bbl vs. Prev. USD 58.0/bbl

subject: ANALYSIS: Potential UK Parliament prorogation ahead
content:
• UK politics has erupted today ahead of the official return of parliament on September 3rd next week. UK PM Johnson has confirmed that parliament will be suspended from around September 9th, and October’s party conference recess to be extended by one week until October 14th for the Queen’s speech.
  • In terms of timings, the prorogation will indicatively take place from September 9th (though some reports do indicate September 11th instead), for around 5 weeks with Parliament to return on October 14th for the Queen’s speech. While some have noted that such a move by the UK Government is unacceptable etc., indications are that it is perfectly legal for this to occur and that there is no scope for legislation to stop the routine process around the Queen’s speech. Regarding the length of the break, while it is somewhat longer than typical as the prior Queen’s speech was two years ago the extended length maybe a justifiable reflection of that.
  • Upon Parliaments return on October 14th, this time will be taken up by debated on the Queen’s speech and then subsequent votes on it leaving very little time to prevent a no-deal; particularly as the European Council conference is on the 17-18th October, which is the effective date for a deal to be agreed upon before the October 31st extension end.
  • As such, the two weeks between September 3rd and 9th/11th are the most likely opportunity for any legislation to stop a no-deal, which has scope as Opposition Leaders have agreed to table a law with the intent of stopping a no-deal alongside over 200 MPs yesterday signing a declaration to continue to run parliament elsewhere in the event it is suspended. On the possibility of a no-confidence vote, this is possible however recently opposition politicians have stated that they do not have the support required for such a vote and that it is their last resort.

ANALYSIS: ROMAN COALITION IN SIGHT?
content:
*THE LATEST: The 5SM and PD parties have until later today to form a coalition after overcoming a hurdle regarding Conte as PM in a potential coalition. A PD lawmaker noted that talks with the 5SM party are progressing in a fruitful way and they will continue their meeting today. PD are willing to accept Conte as PM of a new government, although they wish to limit the role of 5SM leader Di Maio. Sources stated that the main issue is the 5SM leader’s refusal to step down as deputy PM in exchange for Conte resuming the top role. If the parties fail to form a coalition, President Mattarella will name a caretaker government and call for early elections.

*STICKING POINTS: Some hurdles remain between the two parties:

  • Parliamentary reform: One of 5SM’s key demands. The proposal will see the number of MPs in both houses cut from 945 to 600, this has been approved by parliament on three occasions, with the fourth vote due in September. “PD may only agree to this in conjunction with broader constitutional reform” BBC writes.
  • 2020 Budget: Desks note that the two parties are expected to have differences over the 2020 budget which must comply with EU deficit rules.
  • Immigration: The PD party will seek a rollback on immigration measures imposed by the League party. Although these were pushed forward by League leader Salvini, ultimately 5SM agreed to them.
  • Online vote: The 5SM usually puts key strategic decisions to an online vote of its members. Such a move could wreck the potential deal, given that the populist party’s leadership is split between those who favour a coalition with 5SM and those who believe it will hamper voter support. Deputy PM Di Maio said the 5-Star leadership will support a new government only if party members approve it through an online vote planned by next week.

*PEBBLE IN DI MAIO’S SHOE: The FT yesterday reported that activists from the 5SM have threatened to desert the party if it enters into a coalition with the PD. Rome-based 5SM activist Lazzari told the FT that “almost everyone” is against the hypothetical agreement with the PD, “The PD are too pro-Euro, too liberal,” he said. 5SM leader Di Maio has put forth a list of ten policy points for any future coalition.

*SCHEDULE:

subject: Latest ECB call from ABN AMRO (September):
content:
•  Rates: ECB to cut all of its policy rates by 10bps in September, followed by another 10bp step in December. ABN believes the ECB will be reluctant to cut by 20bps all at once next month.
  • Mitigating measures: The ECB is likely to announce measures to mitigate any adverse effects on the banking system of negative interest rates. ECB could also opt to make the conditions for the TLTRO programme more generous.
  • Net asset purchases: ABN expect the ECB to announce a EUR 70bn per month programme running for a year from October 2019 onwards. The Dutch bank believes that policymakers could signal a higher share of corporate bond purchases, agency and regional bond buys than in its first programme.
  • Forward guidance: Following the 10bps deposit rate cut, ABN think the ECB will continue to signal that its key policy rates could be cut further through its forward guidance (as per call for a Dec 10bps cut). Given the re-start of net asset purchases, it could once again link the horizon to the period of QE.
  • Review of inflation aim: ABN do not expect an announcement regarding a formal review of the Bank’s inflation aim. Instead, ABN believe this is something that will be left to Draghi’s successor.

28th August 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets struggled for direction after the subdued performance on Wall St, where the major indices failed to sustain initial gains amid the recent mixed signals on US-China trade and as the US yield curve inversion deepened. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was led higher by strength in tech and miners although gains were capped by weakness in telecoms as Telstra shares declined on ex-dividend day and with earnings in focus including Virgin Australia which was pressured after its annual results remained in the red, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) also lacked firm direction amid an uneventful currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) traded tentative and failed to benefit from the government’s recent announced measures to boost consumption with markets wary after the recent flip-flopping in the US-China trade saga, while a neutral PBoC liquidity operation and deluge of earnings ahead of the Big 4 bank results added to the cautious tone.

FTSE 100

BP (BP/ LN) – Co. has agreed to sell its Alaskan unit to Hilcorp for USD 5.6bln. The sale provides significant progress towards Co’s USD 10bln divestment programme and strategic agenda. The sale will include BP’s entire upstream and midstream business in Alaska. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – FDA has granted orphan drug designation for Fasenra for patients with eosinophilic esophagitis. (Newswires)

UK Oil Names - WTI crude futures traded higher as they caught a bid heading into yesterday’s settlement, with the gains further exacerbated by a much larger than expected drawdown in headline API crude inventories and declining stockpiles across all product components. (RANsquawk)

UK Housing Names – Under plans considered by ministers, first-time home buyers will get discounts of up to 20% on new homes in the area in which they grew up, the cost would be borne by developers. Separately, Housing Secretary Jenrick is announcing a shared ownership scheme designed to get young people and low earners a place on the property ladder; includes, option to purchase homes in 1% sections instead of requiring 10% alongside alterations to the Help to Buy scheme. (Times/Sky)

UK Supermarkets – A Which? Investigation found that shoppers are being misled by special offers/discounts that cost consumers more than buying the products a weak earlier would have. (Sky)

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 28th August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets struggled for direction after the subdued performance on Wall St, where major indices failed to sustain initial gains
  • DXY rests above 98.00 in a mild breakout from the prior day’s flat performance, while its major counterparts were lacklustre
  • Italian Deputy PM Di Maio said the 5-Star leadership will support a new government only if party members approve it through an online vote planned by next week
  • WTI crude futures are firmer with the gains exacerbated by a much larger than expected drawdown in headline API crude inventories
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ M3 Annual Growth, DoEs, Fed Beige Book, Fed’s Barkin, German EUR 3.0bln 2029 & US USD 41bln 5yr auctions

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets struggled for direction after the subdued performance on Wall St, where the major indices failed to sustain initial gains amid the recent mixed signals on US-China trade and as the US yield curve inversion deepened. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was led higher by strength in tech and miners although gains were capped by weakness amid telecoms as and with earnings in focus, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) also lacked firm direction amid an uneventful currency. Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) traded tentatively and failed to benefit from the government’s recent announced measures to boost consumption with markets wary after the recent flip-flopping in the US-China trade saga, while a neutral PBoC liquidity operation and deluge of earnings ahead of the Big 4 bank results added to the cautious tone. Finally, 10yr JGBs were slightly higher as super-long yields declined to multi-year lows with both 30yr and 40yr JGB yields at the lowest since July 2016, while the moves also followed the bull flattening seen in their US counterparts where the 2s/10s inversion briefly widened past -5bps.

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 28-day reverse repo for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0835 vs. Exp. 7.1027 (Prev. 7.0810)

China issued 20 directives to boost domestic consumption which reportedly will make it increasingly difficult for the US to press China to make concessions including gradually relaxing and removing restrictions on auto purchases, as well as building more shopping malls and rolling out state-of-the-art methods for consumers to spend money. (Global Times)

US Federal Register confirmed the US is to raise tariffs on USD 300bln of Chinese goods to 15% from 10% beginning on Friday, while there were separate reports that China will to take in the 2nd batch of tariff exemption applications on September 2nd. (Newswires)

US President Trump’s credibility has become a key obstacle for China with respect to them reaching a deal with the US., according to Chinese officials. (Newswires)

US Department of Defense is in discussions with Australia on processing rare earth minerals as an attempt to lower dependency on China. (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said there will be a no-deal unless the WA was reopened and the backstop abolished but noted they had "positive and substantive" talks with EU Commission President Juncker. (Newswires) EU President Juncker told UK PM Johnson he would look at any concrete proposals as long as they are compatible with the Withdrawal Agreement and that the EU will do everything it can to avoid a no-deal Brexit. Juncker also stated EU 27's support for Ireland is steadfast and they will remain attentive to Ireland's interests, while Irish Foreign Minister Coveney said the new proposals did not fulfil what the backstop did. (Newswires)

UK opposition Labour Party leader Corbyn urged Tory MPs to help block no-deal Brexit, while it was separately reported that former chancellor Hammond plans to spearhead efforts to block a no-deal and intends to advocate a cross-party plan to force a Brexit delay by several months. (Newswires/Telegraph)

UK government is reportedly planning to declare an intention to raise public spending beginning September 4th. However, there were separate reports that UK Chancellor Javid will warn today that the government will not break fiscal rules heading into the Brexit and will not issue blank cheques to Whitehall departments. (FT/Telegraph)

UK BRC Shop Price Index (Aug) Y/Y -0.4% (Prev. -0.1%). (Newswires)

Italy Deputy PM Di Maio said the 5-Star leadership will support a new government only if party members approve it through an online vote planned by next week, while there were comments from a PD lawmaker that talks with the 5-Star party are progressing in a fruitful way and they will continue their meeting on Wednesday. PD are willing to accept Conte as PM of a new government, although they wish to limit the role of current Deputy PM Di Maio (5SM), according to a PD Official. (Newswires)

 

FX

DXY was slightly higher and prodded above the 98.00 level in a mild breakout from the prior day’s flat performance, while its major counterparts were lacklustre in which EUR/USD languished below 1.1100 after recent data confirmed the German economy contracted in Q2 and ECB’s Vice President de Guindos suggested the central bank must act with determination. GBP/USD pulled back after it met resistance around 1.2300 but held on to the majority of the recent gains spurred after UK opposition party leaders met and agreed a legislative route was the most promising path to blocking a no-deal scenario. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was flat amid the inconclusive risk appetite and antipodeans traded subdued as early support from a firmer than expected reference rate setting was overshadowed by disappointing Australian Q2 Construction Work data.

Australian Construction Work Done Q2 -3.8% vs. Exp. -1.0% (Prev. -1.9%, Rev. -2.2%). (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures higher as they caught a bid heading into yesterday’s settlement, with the gains further exacerbated by a much larger than expected drawdown in headline API crude inventories and declining stockpiles across all product components. Elsewhere, gold prices declined as the mild upside in the greenback provided an opportunity to book some of the profits in the precious metal, while copper traded sideways in fitting with the indecisive overnight risk tone.

API Crude Inventories: -11.1mln vs. Exp. -2.1mln (Prev. -3.5mln). (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Photos reportedly suggested North Korea could be building a submarine capable of launching nuclear missiles. (NBC)

US House of Foreign Affairs Committee tweeted that US President Trump must sanction Turkey over its purchase of the S-400 air defense system as required by US law. (Newswires)

 

US

The TPLEX made headway with decisive bull flattening, where the 2-year yield was 2.5bps lower and the 30-year yield fell 7.5bps, taking it beneath the S&P 500 dividend yield for the first time since March 2009. Most of the bid in Fixed came shortly after the US equity open amid haven flows, which helped the 2s10s fall further into inversion, and the TYU9 contract remained firmer through till settlement. At the US 2-year auction, USD 40bln was sold at 1.516%, the lowest yield since September 2017, tailing by 0.1bps (vs. 6-auction average 0.6bps) and an above average bid-to-cover of 2.6x; indirects took slightly more than average, but so did primary dealers, and directs took less than average. US T-note futures (U9) settled 11+ ticks higher at 131-04+.

Fed Discount Rate Minutes stated half of the Fed regional banks wanted no change to the discount rate ahead of the July FOMC meeting in which the directors of New York, Boston, Cleveland, Atlanta, Kansas City, and Richmond Fed wanted no change to the discount rate, while 5 Fed regional banks wanted a 25bps cut and the Minneapolis Fed wanted a 50bps cut. (Newswires)

US President Trump reiterated Fed criticism in which he stated the Fed loves watching our manufacturers struggle with their exports to the benefit of other parts of the world and that the Fed has been calling it wrong for too long. (Twitter)
